review.title: Roadmap Enhanced Improvement to the VSIMM Tracker via a Constrained Stochastic Context Free Grammar
review.abstract: The aim of syntactic tracking is to classify spatio-temporal patterns of a target's motion using natural language processing models. In this paper, we generalize earlier work by considering a constrained stochastic context free grammar (CSCFG) for modeling patterns confined to a roadmap. The constrained grammar facilitates modeling specific directions and road names in a roadmap. We present a novel particle filtering algorithm that exploits the CSCFG model for estimating the target's patterns. This meta-level algorithm operates in conjunction with a base-level tracking algorithm. Extensive numerical results using simulated ground moving target indicator (GMTI) radar measurements show substantial improvement in target tracking accuracy.

metadata.title: Roadmap Enhanced Improvement to the VSIMM Tracker via a Constrained Stochastic Context Free Grammar

sections.heading: II. ROADMAP CONSTRAINED SYNTACTIC TRACKING:
sections.text: The model we propose works on three levels of abstraction. On the top level, we have the roadmap, which is modeled as a directed weighted graph. On the second level, we model the pattern (an ordered sequence of intersection names) of a target on the roadmap as CSCFG. Finally, on the bottom level, the mode sequence q1: k controls the state-related VSIMM spatial model, which has measurements from a GMTI radar image. 1 In simple terms, a CSCFG allows both tree dependencies and serial dependencies. sections.heading: BY CSCFG
sections.text: In this section, we will look at two detailed examples of suspicious (anomalous) trajectories of a target: (i) round trip trajectories indicating a target that encircles an area of interest, and (ii) cost-confined palindromic trajectories indicating a target that traces its path. In both examples, a CSCFG serves as a generative model. These examples generalize our previous work [5] in which SCFGs were used. It is assumed that the target is limited to a square grid shown in Fig. 9 and tracked by a GMTI radar. sections.heading: A. Example 1. Round Trip Model
sections.text: In the circular travel model, which is called Lround, a destination deviates from any node A, arrives at another node B and finally returns to A. On the forward journey, it is assumed that the destination can only move up and right; while on the return journey, the destination can only move down and left. sections.heading: B. Example 2. Cost Constrained Palindrome
sections.text: In a palindrome trajectory model, a target starts from any node A, moves to any node B, and then traces its path to A. Several examples in monitoring include detecting palindrome trajectories of targets. − 4 An example of Lpalindrome is in Fig. 9. Serial dependencies are introduced by taking into account the costs (threat level or fuel consumption) that arise at any given time. − k is modeled by a Markov chain with a state space dependent on xk − 1 and xk.

sections.heading: A. Example 1. Constant Speed Targets
sections.text: Consider the model of Sec. III-B. The velocity of a constant velocity target is an unknown constant, and we assume that its initial10 distribution is evenly distributed among 3 states: 2 m / s, 3 m / s and 4 m / s. The performance of the mode-based syntactic tracker and baseline VSIMM tracker in tracking constant velocity targets among different patterns is shown in Table II. sections.heading: B. Example 2. Average Speed Model
sections.text: Next, we look at the average speed model of Sec. III-C, which is suitable for vehicle traffic. For vehicle traffic, the simulations assume that the speed on the roads is localized and time-changing and is a known constant at intersections (5 m / s); see Table VI in Appendix D. For details, however, the performance of the mode-based syntactic tracker and the baseline of the VSIMM tracker in tracking vehicle traffic is shown in Table III. An example of RMSEs for the two trackers is illustrated in Figure 11 (b). For specific patterns such as v3v0v2 and v9v0v3v8, the mode-based syntactical tracker is much better than 11 of the VSIMM trackers at over 8%. However, there is little difference between the two competing models for the remaining 4 patterns in Table III. Generally speaking, the mode based on syntactical trackers for vehicle traffic is not as drastically improving speed targets.

sections.heading: C. Example 3. Round Trip Model
sections.text: The circular travel model describes a destination that deviates from any node A, arrives at another node B, and then returns to A; see Sec. V-A. The trajectory is limited as follows: The destination moves to its adjacent nodes at each point in time; it moves up and down on the forward journey; on the return journey it moves down and to the left. We present simulations on a 20 x 20 square kilometer grid roadmap with the size of the unit grid as 2 meters (m).The targets are recorded by a GMTI radar with the parameters listed in Table I. The GMTI radar is mounted on an airplane. The aircraft starts at coordinates (-300 m, -300 m) at constant speed (100 m / s in x direction and 20 m / s in y direction).Given the loud GMTI radar measurements, our goal is to calculate the most likely sequence of state x.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we constructed a 3-step model for the syntactical tracking problem of targets whose movement is limited to a roadmap using natural language models; on the first level, the roadmap was modeled as a weighted, directed graph; on the second level, the mode sequence was modeled using a CSCFG; and finally, the base-level kinematics of the target were modeled using a VSIMM. A novel CSCFG-driven particle filtering algorithm was developed to track the kinematics of a target using GMTI measurements; numerical studies show that the mode-based syntactic tracker proposed in this paper can greatly improve tracking accuracy; we also discussed two CSCFG-based models for targets moving on the square grid; and a Viterbi algorithm was illustrated to calculate the most likely hidden state sequence of the target.

sections.heading: APPENDIX A
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A PARSING ALGORITHM FOR THE CONSTRAINED STOCHASTIC CONTEXT FREE GRAMMAR (CSCFG)
sections.text: The parsing algorithm is a modified version of the classic Earley Stolcke parser. This parsing algorithm calculates the probability of entry and the prefix probability. To the best of our knowledge, this algorithm is new. The classic Earley Stolcke parser is used to reconstruct parse trees that generate the input line based on a stochastic context in which the free grammar (SCFG) is free [8]. It generates a sequence of Earley states by scanning, completing, and predicting operations. An Earley state can be written in such a way that the input string is free based on a stochastic context (SCFG). It generates a sequence of Earley states by scanning, completing, and predicting operations.

metadata.abstractText: The aim of syntactic tracking is to classify spatiotemporal patterns of a target’s motion using natural language processing models. In this paper, we generalize earlier work by considering a constrained stochastic context free grammar (CSCFG) for modeling patterns confined to a roadmap. The constrained grammar facilitates modeling specific directions and road names in a roadmap. We present a novel particle filtering algorithm that exploits the CSCFG model for estimating the target’s patterns. This meta-level algorithm operates in conjunction with a base-level tracking algorithm. Extensive numerical results using simulated ground moving target indicator (GMTI) radar measurements show substantial improvement in target tracking accuracy.
